Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Reconstruction of Alpine Aquatic Ecosystem Responses to Temperature Changes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION
GEOGRAPHY SPATIAL SCIENCES (GSS) PROGRAM

ABSTRACT

This doctoral dissertation research will investigate the responses of high elevation aquatic ecosystems to amplified thermal conditions during the Quaternary and the Pleistocene-Holocene periods. Specifically, the research will focus on reconstructing recent and long-term environmental conditions in the alpine and sub-alpine lakes in the Front Range of the Colorado Rockies. New insights will be provided on how the changes in these freshwater systems would affect food web mechanisms, predator/prey dynamics and the expansion of invasive species in these critical ecosystems. Furthermore, the research will advance our understanding of how such changes in the structure, function and composition of aquatic ecosystems would impact access and availability of freshwater resources for recreational and economic use. Findings from this research will provide resource managers with new information that will help in managing the ecological and economic impacts of ongoing environmental changes. The doctoral student will work with government agencies to create and disseminate materials to further public education and outreach. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

The addition of cold, silt-enriched water from accelerated glacial melt into alpine aquatic ecosystems will impact the physical and geochemical conditions of these systems. Understanding the magnitude and rate of change that characterized the transition from the previous glacial to the present interglacial conditions will establish a baseline for comparison of aquatic ecosystem responses to modern thermal amplifications. The doctoral student will conduct a paired study of glaciated and unglaciated lakes to assess the dampening effect of glacial meltwater input on chironomid communities during the recent past and during the Pleistocene-Holocene transition, and document the response of aquatic ecosystems in alpine and subalpine environments to glacial ice retreat. Chironomids are a family of flies and their larvae and pupae are important food items for fish such as trout. To reconstruct past environmental conditions, lake sediment cores will be collected and analyzed for abundance of chironomid remains using Carbon (C) and Nitrogen (N) isotope analyses. The research will apply a chironomid-based inference model to describe changes in the productivity of the aquatic ecosystems through time. Variations in C will be used to track vegetation change within the lake and catchment and fluctuations in N will be used to establish changes in lake productivity as well as the trophic status of the lakes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The last century witnessed abrupt climate and environmental changes that have been pervasive over most of the globe. Alpine and subalpine lakes act as the proverbial canary in a coal mine and are among the first bodies of water impacted by anthropogenically driven increases in temperature. The Intermountain West of the United States is particularly sensitive to changes that affect present and future water availability as many of the these lakes are fed by cold meltwater emanating from glaciers. Climate models suggest alpine glaciers will no longer exist by 2030 which will result in reduced meltwater input and elevated water temperatures in glacially-fed streams and lakes. These changes will negatively impact sensitive aquatic invertebrates. As thermal warming continues, the structure, function, and composition of aquatic ecosystems in alpine and subalpine settings will be dramatically transformed. However, little is understood about the response of insect communities in aquatic ecosystems to past and contemporary episodes of glacial retreat. Insects, such as chironomids, can be extracted from lake sediment and used to develop baseline information against which future changes may be compared. Chironomids are one of the most promising approaches in evaluating the response of high elevation aquatic ecosystems to past changes in climate as they are extremely sensitive to changes in air and water temperature.  This project focused on reconstructing recent and long-term climate and environmental variability in the Front Range of the Colorado Rockies, specifically focusing on episodes of sustained and rapid warming during the late Quaternary, i.e the late 20th and early 21st centuries and the Pleistocene-Holocene transition.

The initial results indicate that differences exist between glacially-fed lakes and those lakes that only received snowmelt. Glacially-fed lakes were characterized by average surface waters temperatures that were 2.62°C cooler than their snowfed partners. Nitrate (NO3) is 66% higher in glacially fed lakes. Chironomid communities and abundance are also markedly different. Glacially-fed lakes are much more diverse and have a much higher percentage of the subfamily Diamesinae, a group of chironomids that are typically found in cold, running water. Snowfed lakes have much lower diversity. Redundancy analysis (RDA) results indicate that both surface water temperature, as well as nitrate were statistically significant and are responsible for the modern distribution of chironomid assemblages. However, when combined, the results were no longer statistically significant. This was verified using Pearson's correlation coefficient which indicated that the variables are highly correlated. Our initial analysis suggests that the mechanism that controls both surface water temperature as well as nitrate (i.e. glacial melt) is responsible for chironomid distribution. Ultimately, once glacial melt is no longer flowing into these alpine and subalpine lakes, water temperatures will increase and chironomid communities will become less diverse.  This finding will aid resource managers in Rocky Mountain National Park by providing key information regarding how benthic invertebrate communities will change in a glacier-free future. These changes will have deleterious effects on ecosystem food web dynamics as well as ecosystem function. Our results may also be used to aid the conservation of the cold-water loving Greenback Cutthroat Trout (Oncorhynchus clarkii stomias). This species is considered to be threatened under the Endangered Species Act. While previous studies have used lake surface temperature models to assess which lakes within the park are viable relocation sites, they failed to include glacial melt as a metric. Our results suggest that while these lakes may possess optimal conditions for the Greenback Cutthroat Trout today, their future is unstable and will ultimately see a dramatic increase in surface water temperature once glaciers are no longer present on the landscape. These results will be shared with staff at Rocky Mountain National Park (RMNP) and will provide a long-term perspective of the linkages that exist between climate variability and aquatic ecosystems in RMNP and the broader Intermountain West.
